page.title: 02Landscape-Biddestone
page.content: The area lies at the southern end of the Cotswold Hills. These hills are made of alternate strata of clay and limestone,some rubbly,some the fine Bath stone. Most of the land is fairly level, the highest point being at 450ft at the west,the land gently falling to 325ft at the east. This land is farmed, the fields enclosed by hedges or stone walls. A small wooded hill lies NE of Biddestone. Running N-S down the western edge of the area, the plateau is cut by the steep sided valley of the Bybrook. The slopes are wooded, with pasture in the bottom of the valley (150 ft). To the SE lies Corsham Park, the grounds of Corsham Court, landscaped by Capability Brown in C18. An avenue of elm trees was destroyed by Dutch Elm disease in recent years.
